dialogue: Look, Pooh, we're at the Zoo! Oh, I can't wait to see the polar bears!
Oh, bother. Can't we just go straight to the honey exhibit?
No, Pooh. We have to see all the animals. That's how it's done.
But I really don't care for any of them except for the bees and their delicious honey.
Well, I have a surprise for you. I know the third keeper from the left and he's going to let us visit the polar bears up close.
(excitedly) Oh, Bear! I can't wait!
(squeaking) What about me?
Don't worry, Piglet. The whole book is about you.
(happily) So it is about me and Pooh!
(grumbling) What about us? No one ever pays attention to poor Eeyore.
(laughing) Oh, Eeyore. Don't be silly. You're an important part of the book too.
Alright, everyone. Let's stop talking about who the book is
Here is Edward Bear, coming downstairs now, bump, bump, bump, on the back of his head, behind me.
Oh, hello Christopher Robin! It's me, Winnie-the-Pooh.
Yes, that's right, Pooh. I'm introducing you to our readers.
Oh, how lovely. I do love making new friends.
When I first heard your name, I was a bit confused.
Why is that, Christopher Robin?
Well, I thought you were a boy, but then I realized you were a bear.
Oh, but my name is Winnie-ther-Pooh. Don't you know what '_ther_' means?
Ah, yes, now I do. It means you're a very special bear.
Oh, thank you, Christopher Robin. Sometimes I like to play games when I come downstairs, but other times I just like to sit and listen to a story.
Well, what do you say? Shall we have a story this evening?
Oh, yes, please! Could you very sweetly tell me a story?
Of course
"What does 'under the name' mean?"
"It means he had the name over the door in gold letters, and lived under it."
"Winnie-the-Pooh wasn't quite sure."
"Now I am."
"Then I will go on."

"One day when he was out walking, he came to an open place in the middle of the forest, and in the middle of this place was a large oak-tree, and, from the top of the tree, there came a loud buzzing-noise."
"That buzzing-noise means something. Perhaps it's a bee."
"He thought another long time, and said: "And the only reason for being a bee that I know of is making honey."
"And the only reason for making honey is so as I can eat it."
"Isn't it funny How a bear likes honey? Buzz! Buzz! Buzz! I wonder why he does?"
"Then he climbed a little further ... and a little further..."

...and then just a little further. By that time he had thought of another song. It's a very funny thought that, if Bears were Bees, They'd build their nests at the bottom of trees. And that being so (if the Bees were Bears), We shouldn't have to climb up all these stairs.
He was getting rather tired by this time, so that is why he sang a Complaining Song.
He was nearly there now, and if he just stood on that branch...
Oh, help!
If only I hadn't...
What I meant to do...
Of course, it was rather...
It all comes, I suppose...
*Watching Pooh fly gracefully into a gorse-bush* Was that me?
*Emerging from the bush* Good morning, Christopher Robin!
Good morning, Winnie-the-Pooh. What brings you here today?
I wonder if you've got such a thing as a balloon about you?
A balloon? What do you want a balloon for?
Oh, there you are! I was beginning to get anxious. I have discovered that the bees are now definitely suspicious.
Shall I put my umbrella up?
Yes, but wait a moment. We must be practical. The important bee to there? No.
A pity. Well, now, if you walk up and down with your umbrella, saying, 'Tut-tut, it looks like rain,' I shall do what I can by singing a little Cloud Song, such as a cloud might sing.... Go!
How sweet to be a Cloud Floating in the Blue!
Christopher--ow!--Robin!
Yes?
I have just been thinking, and I have come to a very important decision. These are the wrong sort of bees.
Are they?
Quite the wrong sort. So I should think they would make the wrong sort of honey, shouldn't you?
Would they?
Yes. So I think I shall come down.
How?
Christopher Robin, you must shoot the balloon with your gun. Have you got your gun?
Of course I have. But if I do that, it will spoil the balloon.
Is that the end of the story?
That's the end of that one. There are others.
About Pooh and Me? And Piglet and Rabbit and all of you. Don't you remember?
I do remember, and then when I try to remember, I forget. That day when Pooh and Piglet tried to catch the Heffalump----
They didn't catch it, did they?
No.
Pooh couldn't, because he hasn't any brain. Did _I_ catch it?
Well, that comes into the story.
I do remember," he said, "only Pooh doesn't very well, so that's why he likes having it told to him again. Because then it's a real story and not just a remembering.
That's just how _I_ feel," I said.
Coming to see me have my bath?
I might," I said.
I didn't hurt him when I shot him, did I?
Not a bit. He nodded and went out, and in a moment I heard Winnie-the-Pooh
-Tra-la-la, tra-la-la,- *stretching up* _Tra-la-la, tra-la--oh, help!--la,_ *trying to reach his toes*
After breakfast, Pooh had said it over and over to himself until he had learnt it off by heart, and now he was humming it right through, properly.
_Tra-la-la, tra-la-la,_ _Tra-la-la, tra-la-la,_ _Rum-tum-tiddle-um-tum._ _Tiddle-iddle, tiddle-iddle,_ _Tiddle-iddle, tiddle-iddle,_ _Rum-tum-tum-tiddle-um._

Well, he was humming this hum to himself, and walking along gaily, wondering what everybody else was doing, and what it felt like, being somebody else, when suddenly he came to a sandy bank, and in the bank was a large hole.
Aha! If I know anything about anything, that hole means Rabbit.
Pooh said as he continued to hum.
And Rabbit means Company. And Company means Food and Listening-to-Me-Humming and such like. *continues humming*
Hallo, Rabbit, isn't that you?
No, but isn't that Rabbit's voice?
Oh!
Well, could you very kindly tell me where Rabbit is?
He has gone to see his friend Pooh Bear, who is a great friend of his.
But this is Me!
What sort of Me?
Pooh Bear. Are you sure?
Quite, quite sure.
Oh, well, then, come in. You were quite right.
Who did you think it was?
Well, I wasn't sure. You know how it is in the Forest. One can't have a mouthful of something?
Pooh always liked a little something at eleven o'clock in the morning, and he was very glad to see Rabbit getting out the plates and mugs.
Honey or condensed milk with your bread?
Both!
Must you?
Well, I could stay a little longer if it--if you----
As a matter of fact, I was going out myself directly.
Oh, well, then
"I've got two names," said Christopher Robin carelessly. Well, there you are, that proves it," said Piglet.
"Hallo!" said Piglet, "what are _you_ doing?
"Hunting," said Pooh.
"Hunting what?"
"Tracking something," said Winnie-the-Pooh very mysteriously.
"Tracking what?" said Piglet, coming closer.
"That's just what I ask myself. I ask myself, What?
"What do you think you'll answer?"
"I shall have to wait until I catch up with it," said Winnie-the-Pooh.
"Now, look there." He pointed to the ground in front of him. "What do you see there?
"Tracks," said Piglet. "Paw-marks." He gave a little squeak of excitement. "Oh, Pooh! Do you think it's a--a--a Woozle?"
"Hello Eeyore, how are you today?"
"Not very well, Pooh. I haven't felt well in a long time."
"Oh dear, that's not good. Let me have a look at you."
*stands there sadly*
*walks around Eeyore* "Why, what's happened to your tail?"
"I don't know. It's just gone."
"Are you sure? You can't make a mistake about a tail."
"I'm pretty sure it's not there."
"Let's have a look."
*turns around slowly*
"Oh my, you're right. Your tail is missing."
"Yes, and I don't know where it could have gone."
"Don't worry, Eeyore. We'll find it. Let's go ask our friends if they've seen it."
"Thank you, Pooh. That would be very kind of you."
"Of course, Eeyore. We're friends, and friends help each other."
"Lumping along," said Christopher Robin. "I don't think it saw _me_."
"I saw one once," said Piglet. "At least, I think I did," he said. "Only perhaps it wasn't."
"So did I," said Pooh, wondering what a Heffalump was like.
"You don't often see them," said Christopher Robin carelessly.
"Not now," said Piglet. "Not at this time of year," said Pooh.

"Piglet said, "If you see what I mean, Pooh," and Pooh said, "It's just what I think myself, Piglet," and Piglet said, "But, on the other hand, Pooh, we must remember," and Pooh said, "Quite true, Piglet, although I had forgotten it for the moment."
"Piglet, I have decided something."
"What have you decided, Pooh?"
"I have decided to catch a Heffalump."
"How?"
"I shall do it by means of
"But supposing it were raining already?"
"Oh, I hadn't thought of that."
"But if it were raining, the Heffalump would be looking at the sky and wouldn't see the pit until he was halfway down."
"Yes, that's very clever, Pooh. A cunning trap indeed."
"Now we just need to figure out where to dig the pit."
"Maybe somewhere where the Heffalump would be walking, just before he fell into it."
"But then he would see us digging it."
"Not if he was looking at the sky."
"Ah, but what if he happens to look down?"
"Hmm, that's a good point. It's not as easy as we thought."
"That's why Heffalumps hardly ever get caught."
"That must be it."
"If only I could think of something."
"Well, if I were trying to catch you, I would do it like this."
I should make a Trap, and I should put a Jar of Honey in the Trap, and you would smell it, and you would go in after it, and----

And I would go in after it, only very carefully so as not to hurt myself, and I would get to the Jar of Honey, and I should lick round the edges first of all, pretending that there wasn't any more, you know, and then I should walk away and think about it a little, and then I should come back and start licking in the middle of the jar, and then----

Yes, well never mind about that. There you would be, and there I should catch you. Now the first thing to think of is, What do Heffalumps like? I should think acorns, shouldn't you? We'll get a lot of----
I say, wake up, Pooh!
Huh? Oh, sorry Piglet. I was just dreaming about catching a Heffalump.
Oh dear. Did you come up with a plan?
Yes, I did. We'll set a trap with honey and acorns. That's what Heff
Oh bother, someone's been eating all my honey!
(licking its jaws) Very good honey this, I don't know when I've tasted better.
(jumping out of bed) I can't bear it any longer, I must go check on my honey!
(excitedly) Oh, there it is! My jar of honey at the bottom of the very deep pit!
(getting his nose inside the jar) Bother! A Heffalump has been eating it!
(waking up and noticing Pooh's distress) Oh no, what happened?
(embarrassed) I forgot, I was the one who ate it all.
(comforting) It's okay, Pooh. We can always get more honey.
(thoughtfully) You're right, Piglet. What was I thinking about anyway?
(curious) What were you thinking about, Pooh?
(excitedly) Heffalumps! I was wondering what they're like and if they come when you whistle
I just don't know what to do, Pooh. What if the Heffalump is very fierce and doesn't like Pigs and Bears?
Oh, Piglet, you worry too much. We'll go together and be very careful. And if the Heffalump is not there, we'll just go back to bed.
But what if it is there?
Then we'll come up with a plan. We always do, don't we?
I suppose so. But what if it's scary?
We'll be brave, Piglet. And if we need to, we'll run away as fast as we can.
Okay, I guess I'll try to be brave.
That's the spirit, Piglet. Now let's go and see what's in the trap.
's the matter?
Nothing, Pooh Bear, nothing. We can't all, and some of us don't. That's all there is to it.
Can't all what?
Gaiety. Song-and-dance. Here we go round the mulberry bush.
Oh! What mulberry bush is that?
Bon-hommy. French word meaning bonhommy. I'm not complaining, but There It Is.
(sitting down) It sounded to me like a riddle. I'm not very good at riddles.
Cottleston, Cottleston, Cottleston Pie, A fly can't bird, but a bird can fly. Ask me a riddle and I reply: Cottleston, Cottleston, Cottleston Pie.
(still gloomy) Cottleston, Cottleston, Cottleston Pie.
Cottleston, Cottleston, Cottleston Pie, Why does a chicken, I don't know why. Ask me a riddle and I reply: Cottleston, Cottleston,
You... giving him, Pooh?
I'm giving him a Useful Pot to Keep Things In, and I wanted to ask you----
Is this it?
Yes, and I wanted to ask you----
Somebody has been keeping honey in it.
You can keep anything in it. It's Very Useful like that. And I wanted to ask you----
You ought to write 'A Happy Birthday' on it. That was what I wanted to ask you.
Because my spelling... wrong places.
Would you write 'A Happy Birthday' on it for me?
It's a nice pot.
Couldn't I give it too? From both of us?
No, that would not be a good plan. Now I'll just wash it first, and then you can write on it.
Well, he washed the pot out, and dried it, while Owl licked the end of his pencil, and wondered how to spell "birthday.
Can you read, Pooh?
There's a notice about knocking and ringing outside my door, which Christopher Robin wrote. Could you read it
(running towards Eeyore) Good morning, Eeyore!
(not looking up) Good morning, Little Piglet.
(noticing Eeyore's deflated balloon) Oh dear, did your balloon pop?
(sighing) Yes, it seems to have gone missing.
(excitedly) Oh, I know! I saw it floating towards my house and I thought it was a gift for me!
(chuckles) Sorry to disappoint you, Piglet.
(determined) Well, let's go find it and fix it up for you. We can't have you without a balloon on your birthday.
(smiling) That's very kind of you, Piglet. But I think it's too late.
(sadly) Oh, I'm sorry.
(patting Piglet's head) It's okay, Piglet. The thought counts.
(smiling) I'll make it up to you somehow, Eeyore. I promise.
(grateful) Thank you, Pig
"Not mine," said Eeyore proudly. "Look, Piglet!"
"And it comes out!"
"Doesn't it?"
"So it does!" said Pooh. "It goes in!"
"So it does!" said Piglet. "And it comes out!"
"It goes in and out like anything."
"I'm very glad," said Pooh happily, "that I thought of giving you a Useful Pot to put things in."
"I'm very glad," said Piglet happily, "that I thought of giving you Something to put in a Useful Pot."
"And didn't _I_ give him anything?" asked Christopher Robin sadly.
Of course you did," I said. "You gave him--don't you remember--a little--a little----
"I gave him a box of paints to paint things with."
That was it. "Why didn't I give it to him in the morning?"
"You were so busy getting his party ready for him. He had a cake with icing on the top, and
Hello Piglet, have you heard the news?
What news, Pooh?
About the Strange Animal that has come to the Hundred Acre Wood.
What I don't like about it is this.
Here we are, all of us, and then suddenly we have a new animal among us.
And Eeyore.
Oh, and Eeyore. I was forgetting him.
Yes, and Owl too.
Oh, and Owl. And then all of a sudden--
And then suddenly we wake up one morning and find ourselves with a Strange Animal.
An animal who carries her family in her pocket.
Imagine if I carried my family in my pocket, how many pockets I would need.
Sixteen, isn't it?
Seventeen, actually.
Oh, I make it fifteen.
Fifteen what?
For your family.
What about them?
You were talking about your family, right?
Oh, never mind, Pooh.
The real question
(in a husky voice) And afterwards?
What do you mean? When Kanga discovers the difference?
Then we all say "Aha!"
All three of us?
Yes, that's how it works.
Oh, I see. Why do you ask?
No reason, Piglet. As long as we all say it, it's fine.
I understand. I wouldn't want to say "Aha!" by myself either. By the way, are you sure about what you said regarding the winter months?
The winter months?
Yes, about being fierce only in the winter months.
Oh, yes, that's right. Well, what do I have to do?
You just have to talk to Kanga very hard, so she doesn't notice anything.
Talk about what?
Anything you like. Like reciting a bit of poetry.
That's it, Pooh. Now come along.
Good afternoon
"I don't know if you are interested in Poetry at all?"
"Hardly at all."
"Oh! Roo, dear, just one more jump and then we must go home."
"Go on."
"Talking of Poetry, I made up a little piece as I was coming along. It went like this."
"Fancy!"
"Now Roo, dear, you'll like this piece of poetry."
"You'll love it."
"You must listen very carefully."
"So as not to miss any of it."
"Oh, yes. How did it go, Pooh?"
"Now is it true, or is it not, That what is which and which is what?"
"Yes, it is, isn't it?"
"Just one more jump, Roo, dear, and then we really must be going."
"Talking of Poetry, have you ever noticed that tree right over there?"
"Where?"
"Right over there."
"No."
"Now jump in,
"An Ambush," said Owl, "is a sort of Surprise."
"So is a gorse-bush sometimes," said Pooh.
"An Ambush, as I was about to explain to Pooh," said Piglet, "is a sort of Surprise."
"If people jump out at you suddenly, that's an Ambush," said Owl.
"It's an Ambush, Pooh, when people jump at you suddenly," explained Piglet.
"Pooh, who now knew what an Ambush was, said that a gorse-bush had sprung at him suddenly one day when he fell off a tree, and he had taken six days to get all the prickles out of himself."
"We are not _talking_ about gorse-bushes," said Owl a little crossly.
"I am," said Pooh.

"They were climbing very cautiously up the stream now, going from rock to rock, and after they had gone a little way they came to a place where the banks widened out at each side, so that on each side of the water there was a level strip of
"Ow!" He got up, and looked behind him.
"Yes, I was. I thought so. Thank you, Pooh. If you've quite finished with it." He moved across to take a closer look.
"It don't do them any Good, you know, sitting on them," he went on, as he looked up munching. "Takes all the Life out of them. Remember that, Christopher Robin."
"Others, makes all the difference." As soon as he had finished his lunch he whispered to Rabbit, and Rabbit said "Yes, yes, of course," and they walked a little further away.
"I didn't want the others to hear."
"Quite so," said Rabbit, looking important.
"It's--I wondered--It's only--Rabbit, I suppose _you_ don't know, What does the North Pole _look_ like?"
"Well, now you're asking me. I did know once, only I've sort of forgotten."
"It's a funny thing, but I've sort of forgotten too, although I did know _once_."
"So much for washing," said Eeyore, grumbling to himself as he watched Roo fall into the water.
"Roo's fallen in!" cried Rabbit, running over to the pool with Christopher Robin.
"Are you all right, Roo dear?" called Christopher Robin, concerned for his friend.
"Yes!" squeaked Roo from the water. "Look at me sw--" and he went under again.
"Are you sure you're all right, Roo dear?" called Kanga, hopping along the bank.
"Look at me swimming!" Roo exclaimed proudly, before going under again.
"In a case of Sudden and Temporary Immersion, the Important Thing is to keep the Head Above Water," Owl explained to the others.
"I'll get something to help," said Pooh, grabbing a long pole and heading towards the water.
"I'll help too," said Kanga, taking the other end of the pole and holding it across the lower part of the pool.
"Look at me swimming!" Roo exclaimed, still bubbling with excitement as he drifted towards the pole.
"We
Hello Piglet, isn't this weather just grand?
Oh no, Pooh, it's quite dreadful. I should think poor old Rabbit is about flooded out by this time.
Oh, bother. I forgot about Rabbit. It would have been jolly to talk like this, and really, it wasn't much good having anything exciting like floods, if you couldn't share them with somebody.
Yes, it is rather exciting. The little streams have become rivers and the river has sprawled out of its own bed. I'm starting to worry if it will come into my bed soon.
Oh, dear. That does sound a bit concerning. What are you going to do?
I don't know, Pooh. I'm just a very small animal surrounded by water and I can't do anything.
Don't worry, Piglet. I may not have much brain, but I'm sure I can think of something.
What do you think we should do?
Hmm, well, I remember a story Christopher Robin told me about a man on a desert island who wrote something in a bottle and threw it in the sea.
"I've decided to go on an Expotition to discover the East Pole by myself."
"But Pooh, I had something else planned for you and Kanga today."
"That's alright, I can go on my own. I'll find it, I promise."
"Well, just be careful, Pooh. The East Pole can be a dangerous place."
"Don't worry, I'll be fine. I'll bring back something special for you."
"Alright, but don't forget to come back for supper."
"I won't forget. See you later, Christopher Robin."
"Well, did you find the East Pole, Pooh?"
"I think so. I had a very strange dream while I was napping. I was at the East Pole, and it was very cold."
"Oh my, that does sound like the East Pole. What happened in your dream?"
"I found a bee-hive to sleep in, but there wasn't enough room for my legs. And then these Wild Woozles came and nibbled
"We might go in your umbrella."
*mouth open and eyes staring* "Is this really the Bear of Very Little Brain I know?"
*getting in the umbrella* "It's all right now."
*opening umbrella* "Let's call this boat 'The Brain of Pooh'."
*excitedly* "I can't wait to tell everyone about our adventure!"
"I'm glad we're back into safety. Did you see any interesting things while I was gone?"
*smiling* "Yes, I saw a beautiful ship coming to rescue me. It had a captain named Christopher Robin and a first mate named Pooh Bear."
*laughing* "That sounds like a wonderful ship. I'm glad we're together again."
Oh, that's what it's for, is it?
Yes, so will you tell Pooh as quickly as you can, and all the others, because it will be to-morrow.
Oh, it will, will it?
Yes, it will. So will you go and tell them, Owl?
Christopher Robin is giving a party? Oh!
A party for me? How grand! Will there be those little cake things with pink sugar icing?
"Oh, bother," said Pooh, rubbing his head. "I can't quite remember what the party is for."
"Perhaps it's for Christopher Robin's birthday," suggested Piglet.
"Oh, yes, that could be it," said Pooh, his face brightening up. "But then, who knows. Maybe it's for something else entirely."
"What do you mean?" asked Piglet, puzzled.
"I was just thinking," said Pooh, his voice dreamy. "The more I try to remember, the more the party becomes like a muddled dream in my mind."
"Oh dear," said Piglet sympathetically. "Maybe you should sing your Anxious Pooh Song to help you remember."

"Oh, yes, my Anxious Pooh Song!" exclaimed Pooh, starting to sing. "3 Cheers for Pooh! (_For Who?_) For Pooh-- (_Why what did he do?_) I thought you knew; He saved his friend from a wetting! 3 Cheers for Bear! (_For where?_) For Bear-- He couldn't swim, But he rescued him! (_
What's that you've got there?
It's an invitation to a party, Eeyore. From Christopher Robin.
Ah, I see. Piglet's excited ears must have dropped it.
No, no! It's for you, Eeyore.
Are you sure? Christopher Robin said to tell all of them.
Yes, all of them. That includes you, Eeyore.
Well, I suppose I'll come. But don't blame me if it rains.
But it won't rain, Eeyore. Christopher Robin has made a long table for all of us to sit at together.
Hallo, Pooh!
Hallo, Roo! Are you excited for your first party?
Yes, I can't wait to talk to everyone!
It'll probably rain soon. Just wait and see.
Really? I'll keep an eye out.
When you wake up in the morning, Pooh, what's the first thing you say to yourself?
What's for breakfast?
What do you say, Piglet?
I say, I wonder what's going to happen exciting to-day?
It's the same thing.
And what did happen?
Next morning. I don't know.
Could you think and tell me and Pooh some time?
If you wanted it very much.
Pooh does.
He gave a deep sigh, picked his bear up by the leg and walked off to the door, trailing Winnie-the-Pooh behind him. At the door he turned and said, "Coming to see me have my bath?"
I might," I said.
Was Pooh's pencil case any better than mine?
It was just the same," I said.
He nodded and went out...and in a moment I heard Winnie-the-Pooh--bump, bump, bump--going up the stairs behind him.
